titleInfo.title: Structural and Environmental Characteristics of Non-Tropical Marine Miniature Supercells

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Non-tropical marine miniature supercells are storms that occur in the southeastern United States and over large bodies of water, such as the Gulf of Mexico. Those that form offshore of the Florida Panhandle prompt many special marine warnings and, if they make landfall, may also require tornado warnings. They exhibit characteristics of both miniature supercells found in tropical cyclones (TCs) and midlatitude supercells. The marine supercells within this study consist of storms with 40-dBZ lengths < 20 km ("miniature") and > 20 km ("low-topped"), with all having average lifetime echo tops < 30 kft. Utilizing WSR-88D radar data, this study finds that non-TC marine miniature supercells exhibit weak mesocyclones in terms of rotational velocity, are small in diameter, and have values of vertical vorticity comparable to their larger counterparts in the Midwest. Likewise, their mesocyclones are comparable to those in TC-rainbands, particularly in terms of depth, strength, and horizontal size. Echo tops of the non-tropical marine miniature supercells also are found to be similar to TC-rainband miniature supercell heights. "Miniature" supercells within the study dataset exhibit statistically significant linear relationships between echo tops and 40-dBZ contour length and between mesocyclone depth and 40-dBZ length. Uncovering these relationships may help forecasters locate small mesocyclones in miniature marine supercells, or infer mesocyclones located below radar beam level. Results show that non-tropical marine miniature supercells occur in a range of different environments. However, average environmental characteristics taken from the Rapid Update Cycle (RUC) and Rapid Refresh (RAP) show similarities to both midlatitude and TC-miniature supercells. Thermodynamic instability (CAPE) is relatable between the midlatitude, TC-miniature, and non-TC marine supercells. 0-6 km shear is greater in non-tropical storms than those found in TCs, with values greater than 20 m sâˆ’1. However, lower-level tropospheric vertical wind shear and SRH values are much greater in TC supercells than in non-tropical miniature marine supercells. Tornadic storms within the study dataset exhibit lower values of significant tornado parameters (STPs) and supercell composite parameters (SCP) compared to TC-rainband tornadic supercells, but their values still indicate environments capable of producing right-moving supercells with tornadoes.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Florida, Gulf of Mexico, miniature, supercells, Tallahassee, waterspouts
Henry E. Fuelberg, Professor Directing Thesis; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member; Vasubandhu Misra, Committee Member.
